Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure.reason: The course's fundamental focus is the 'Semiconductor Industry,' 'Technological innovation,' and the reorganization of 'technological supply chains,' which are the essence of this SDG.

Reduced Inequalities.reason: The course analyzes geopolitical and economic power dynamics between nations, such as the 'U.S.–China high-tech competition' and Taiwan's transition from 'periphery' to 'core'.
evidence: transition from the “periphery” to the “core” of the global supply chain

Responsible Consumption and Production.reason: The course extensively analyzes the 'reorganizing technological supply chains' and 'global semiconductor production,' which are central to production patterns, though without an explicit sustainability focus.
evidence: cascading effects of global supply-chain restructuring

Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions.reason: The course is centered on legal and institutional frameworks, including 'national-level regulations,' 'export controls,' and 'governance frameworks' that shape 'national security and the global order.'
evidence: forging new governance frameworks and industrial strategies

Partnerships for the Goals.reason: The course analyzes international policy and economic relationships, including 'U.S.–China high-tech competition,' 'Taiwan‑U.S. Semiconductor Security,' and potential 'EU–Japan–US Cooperation,' all facets of global partnerships.
evidence: The Case for an EU–Japan–US Cooperation Framework
